title: . Anatomical and Functional Classification in Dento-Facial Asymmetries and Therapeutic Implications: A Preliminary Report
abstract: The aim of this study was to evaluate the degree of facial asymmetry and malocclusion in 42 patients who underwent surgical treatment due to muscular torticollis. Tenotomy of the muscle-tendon attachment of the sternocleidomastoid muscle was performed in all cases in the Dept. of Orthopedic Surgery. Average age of patients at the time of operation was 8.5 years. Assessment of the results of surgical treatment was based on the range of movements of the neck and presence of head tilt. Facial asymmetry was evaluated on the basis of clinical examination, photographs, (photostatic) analysis of diagnostic models, anteroposterior skull radiograms and orthopantomograms of the jaws. Severe or moderate facial asymmetry of the mid-and/or lower face was diagnosed in 33 (78.6 %) cases. In 32 (76.2%) of the patients facial asymmetry coexisted with lateral malocclusion (partial anterior crossbite, total lateral occlusion). Based on the findings in this study, we conclude that the degree of facial asymmetry in patients with muscular torticollis is related to timing of surgery and severity of the deformity. There is especially an apparent relationship between lower face asymmetry and coexisting malocclusion.

body_text.text: Dento-facial asymmetries are, except deformities caused by tumours or congenital syndromes, an expression of deficit or excess of the skeleton and can be classified in three groups : mandibular asymmetries, maxillo-mandibular asymmetries, and cranio-maxillo-mandibular asymmetries. It is obvious that surgical correction should involve the skeletal parts that are directly affected.

Electromyographic studies show that there are two different patterns of muscular activity in maxillo-mandibular asymmetries. Preoperatively we examined 12 patients. 6 had a normal muscular activity, 6 had an abnormal muscular activity with an asymmetric pattern and hypertonia. Muscular response to surgical correction was clearly different in these two groups. When these preliminary observations will be confirmed in a larger number of patterns, the surgical approach may have to be modified to the muscular pattern.

Dept. of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Fac. of Medicine. Montpellier, France The occlusion should be of prime concern when considering diagnosis and treatment of patients with facial asymmetries. In general two different situations can be distinguished: 1. Normal occlusion that should be maintained. The skeletal correction should be carried out without disturbing the existing occlusion. This is mainly the case for congenital and early acquired deformation 2. Malocclusion, often with cross bite and tilting of the occlusal plane. Correction should aim at correcting the intermaxillary relationship as well as the occlusal plane.

body_text.text: Unilateral TMJ condylar hyperplasia is generally characterised by a slowly developing, progressive enlargement of the condyle and elongation of the mandibular neck resulting in facial asymmetry and shifting of the midline of the chin to the unaffected side. Hemimandibular hyperplasia is characterised by the condylar hyperplasia features and also by an elongation of the ascending ramus of the mandible and increased height of the mandibular body and compensatory maxillary growth. The aetiology is unknown. Diagnosis and treatment modalities of 13 patients (1983) (1984) (1985) (1986) (1987) (1988) (1989) (1990) (1991) (1992) (1993) 10 female, 3 male, age 18-63 years) with an unilateral condylar hyperplasia or hemimandibular hyperplasia have been evaluated. Clinical, roentgenological and scintigraphic findings are included. A condylectomy was performed in all cases, independent of the outcome of the bone scan (positive N = 11, negative N-~ 2). A striking decrease in facial asymmetry was observed starting immediately after operation and carrying on until 1.5-2 years postoperative. Maximum occlusion was achieved by spontaneous migration of the upper and lower teeth and movement of the alveolar process backward to a neutral position on the body of the mandible. Orthodontic support was necessary in four cases and supplementary bimaxillary orthognathic surgery for further correction of remaining facial asymmetry was indicated in three cases.

body_text.text: In conclusion: Condylectomy proved to be a successful treatment modality for TMJ unilateral condylar hyperplasia and hemimandibular hyperplasia. Supplementary orthognathic surgery can be omitted in most cases.

body_text.text: Dept. Oral-Maxillofacial Surg., Aristotle University, Thessaloniki, Greece Correction of the maxillofacial skeleton is of prime concern in patients with hemifacial microsomia. This is usually achieved with osteostomies performed in the mandible as well as in the middle third of the facial skeleton. In-most patients there remains an obvious lack of soft tissue bulk. body_text.text: In the last 8 years we have used pericranial or osteopericranial flaps pedicied to the superficial temporal vessels for the correction of facial asymmetry in 13 patients. Of those, 8 patients had Romberg's disease, 2 patierits hemifacial microsomia and 1 patient Hanhart syndrome. The pericranial flap consisted of galea and periosteum and the osteopericranial flap consisted of calvarial bone pedicied to the galea and the periosteum, In order to achieve a satisfactory tissue volume it was necessary to create a doubled flap. In the majority of patients, especially in younger ones, osteopericranial flaps with full thickness parietal bone were used to achieve a satisfactory facial contour, it was also possible, as a one stage procedure, to combine a osteopericranial flap with additional pericranial flaps to correct the most severe facial asymmetries. body_text.text: AcCording to Obwegeser and Makek' hemimandibular hyperplasia is characterised by a three dimensional enlargement of the condyle, condylar neck and the ascending and , horizontal rami terminating at the symphysis. 13 patients, fitting the clinical and radiographical features of hemimandibular hyperplasia were available for a retrospective evaluation. The long-term results were analyzed clinically and radiographically, the functional status determined and the mandibular movements recorded simultaneously with electromyography, in 8 patients a condylectomy was performed, while 9 remodelling osteotomies were done. Several patients underwent additional orthognathic procedures and 2 patients were not operated at all. All patients showed late onset of the mandibular deformity and mostly reported a limited duration of the overgrowth. Bone scintigraphy did not seem to be a reliable method to determine the actual pathological growth activity of the condyle. During follow~up, 3 of the patients who underwent condylectomy, had increasing functional complaints. For this reason in one patient condylar reconstruction with a costochondral graft was done. The other patients (without condylectomy) showed only minimal functional disturbances.

body_text.text: Evaluation of the patients with remodelling osteotomies showed that intraoral reduction of the caudally displaced mandibular angle and horizontal ramus was a difficult surgical procedure. There appeared to be a high risk for nerve damage and overcorrection. This feature was aggravated by a substantial bone resorption of the inferior mandibular border in the years following the operation. Based on this experience we suggest the following treatment concept: When feasible the enlarged condyle should be left in situ and one should refrain from surgery until growth activity has ceased. The alignment of dental arches is achieved by orthodontics and orthognatic surgery. The facial symmetry can be improved by a limited remodelling osteotomy.

body_text.text: Dept. of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong 53 patients (31F, 22M) with idiopathic mandibular asymmetry and high condylar isotope uptake, and who had periodical repeat scintigram, were analysed. Three age groups were identified, 13 to 20, 21 to 25 and > 26, with statistically significant difference in isotope uptake between the groups both for the high and low uptake sides. Males showed significantly higher uptake than females both at high and low uptake sides, and on first and repeat scintigram. Statistical analysis of paired scintigraphic results and standardised measurements of date-matched radiographs showed that ramus length and condylar neck length were significantly larger for the high uptake side, with the ratio of condylar neck to ramus length increasing with the magnitude of isotope uptake on both sides. Ramus length also increases between repeated active scans. The magnitude of uptake on the high uptake side decreases with repeated scans, but no statistical relation is found on the low uptake side. This analysis supports the clinical hypothesis that continued mandibular growth in asymmetry mostly occurs by condylar neck elongation on the affected side, but this is also shown to occur on the normal side in association with a frequently encountered persistent increase in isotope uptake.

body_text.text: The aim of surgical correction of the frontal and orbital deformity in craniosynostosis is to create normal frontal convexity, i.e. a correct naso-frontal relation, and a symmetric and harmonious orbital shape and size. This presentation discusses the most suitable surgical technique, taking in consideration the age of the patient, type and severity of the craniosynostosis.

body_text.text: A retrospective study of the results obtained after surgical treatment of 61 patients with craniosynostotic fronto-orbital deformity is made. The minimal follow up is 1 year. The survey included: Scaphocephaly (2), Trigonocephaly (5), Plagiocephaly (31), Brachycephaly (4), Oxycephaly (1), Apert's S. (7), Crouzon's S. (7), Pfeiffer's S. (2), Carpenter's S. (1) and Saethre-Chotzen's S. (1). The severity of the craniosynostosis is defined by the site and number of sutures involved, functional repercussions and morphologic expression. There are two groups which require a different approach: i.e. early age (growth not finished yet) and adults. At early age, depending on the severity, frontal remodelling is preferably obtained by frontal bone rotation, with or without splitting, or by transposition of a frontal or parietal segment. The remodelling of the fronto-naso-orbital segment is performed by bilateral differential mobilisation in several directions, with or without bone grafts. In adults, frontal remodelling may be obtained by insertion of alloplastic material.

Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Wilhelms-University of Westfalen, Miinster, Germany Craniofacial malformations are usually diagnosed at birth, or sometimes even before and they usually cause skull deformities often associated with brain and eyeball pressure. These symptoms urge the surgeon to intervene at a very early age. Over the last 10 years it became obvious that radical ostectomy is superior to strip osteotomy in the treatment of craniosynostosis. Radical ostectomy gives rise to normal growth of both the neurocranium and the viscerocranium along with simultaneous release of intracranial pressure. The procedure must be carried out in the first weeks of life to take full advantage of the skull's growth potential and to achieve complete reossification. For craniosynostosis in non-syndrome patients, this one step procedure usually gives complete normalisation of skull growth. For malformation syndrome patients such as Crouzon or Apert we prefer a 3-step procedure:

body_text.text: The objective of the study is to evaluate the vascular architecture in the human temporalis muscle for surgical application. 24 human temporalis muscles were harvested from 12 fresh cadavers. The intra-muscular vessels were infused prior to harvesting with indian ink in 8 muscles, lead oxide solution in 10 muscles, and methyl-methacrylate resin in 6 muscles. The method of analyses on the indian ink specimens was by stereomicroscope, lead oxide specimens by radiography and computerised image analyser, and methyl-methacrylate specimens by corrosion cast technique. Results showed that the human temporalis muscle was supplied by 3 main arteries: the anterior and posterior deep temporal arteries, and middle temporal artery. There was primary, secondary and tertiary branching within each blood supply. Furthermore, multiple anastomosing secondary arteries were noted to connect the 3 main vascular territories. In the sagittal plane, the vessels were located mainly on the lateral and medial aspects with a less vascular plane in the middle. The various arteries were accompanied by their corresponding venous network.

body_text.text: Total facial rehabilitation (TFR) requires an understanding of the contributing components of the so called ageing face syndrome. This syndrome may be due to atrophy of the jaws, or resulting from ablative surgery for cancer. The ageing face requires correction of every anatomical component i.e. facial skeleton, dento-alveolar part and soft tissues. The surgical armamentarium includes : maxillofacial osteotomies, autogenous bone grafts, biomaterials, internal rigid fixation and other ancillary procedures. The introduction of endosseous implants has allowed the surgeon to use a stable base on which a prosthesis can be made with functional and aesthetic long-lasting results. Last, but not least, repositioning of the facial mask is the 'final touch' for these complex reconstructive procedures. The concept of TFR may be considered as an evolution of reconstructive surgery. Surgical strategies, new technologies as well as clinical cases will be presented.

Helical CT data is used to create a 3-dimensional model of the defect skull. This numerically based model serves as the basis for a freeform surface design of the implant's shape, position and thickness. The data required for this geometric contouring are derived from the structures neighbouring the defect. Modelling tools and programs developed for industrial CAD/CAM are used. The precise and individual fit of the implant results from generating its margins by the margins of the defect whereas the implant's surface is generated by the geometry of the non-affected neighbouring bone contours. The computer-based geometric data of the implant then numerically control a milling machine to fabricate the individual implant. The reconstruction of post traumatic contour-defects of the forehead and of temporal defects after surgery for intracranial bleedings are presented as the first clinical experiences of this new method.
body_text.section: Dept. of Oral & Maxillofacial Surgery 1, Radiology 2 & Neurosurgery 3, University Hospital Knappschaftskrankenhaus and CIP-Konstruktion Co. 4, Bochum, Germany

body_text.text: 1 The Hospital for Sick Children, Toronto, Canada, 2 Hopital Enfants Malades, Paris, France Solid coral blocks have been used as a bone graft substitute in clinical orthopaedics for over 12 years. In this study 36 patients with 54 craniofacial osseous contour defects received subperiosteal augmentations with natural coral granules made chiefly of calcium carbonate. The patients were followed for 12 to 36 months. The post operative results were satisfactory with only 5 sites of clinically evident resorption. There were 2 cases of wound irritation and one instance of overt infection. Technical aspects of the procedure are discussed.

body_text.text: Split calvarian autogenous grafting has proved to be a successful procedure in skull reconstruction competing with a great variety of alloplastic materials. The prerequisite for limited resorption of the graft and for a low risk of infection are: 1. optimal contact between graft and the recipient bone margins of the defect and 2. rigid fixation of the graft. A step-like preparation of the defect margins is recommended and graft fixation with micro plates or micro lag screws is usually possible. In smaller defects (up to 4-5 cm diameter) outer table grafts can be harvested by the extra cranial splitting technique. Larger defects usually require full thickness bone flaps and splitting.
body_text.section: Dept. of Maxillofacial Surgery, University Hospital Ggttingen, Germany

body_text.text: Particularly defects of the lateral forehead region including the supra orbital rim and the zygomatic process require additional sandwich onlay grafts with simple lag screw fixation on top of the defect-bridging graft to enhance the aesthetic result.
body_text.section: Dept. of Maxillofacial Surgery, University Hospital Ggttingen, Germany

body_text.text: In a series of 20 cases, including major defects up to 21 x 16 cm in size, no infection occurred. The technique of calvarian split grafting and rigid fixation appeared to be safe. However, in 2 cases of major defects a certain degree of graft resorption was observed. Indications and technique of skull reconstruction are demonstrated by selected clinical cases.
body_text.section: Dept. of Maxillofacial Surgery, University Hospital Ggttingen, Germany

body_text.text: Microvascular surgery has created major advances in the reconstruction of the oral cavity after ablative surgery. In our department the most common flaps used for this type of reconstruction are the jejunum flap and the radial forearm flap. The principal advantages of the jejunum free flap versus the radial forearm flap are the absence of a scarred graft, hair growth and desquamation; the disadvantages are the need for a second surgical team, the excessive mucous production during the first week after surgery that can lead to aspiration severe enough to cause pneumonia and thus increased patient morbidity.
body_text.section: Department of Maxillofacial Surgery, University of Rome 'La Sapienza', Italy

body_text.text: In a two-years period (1992) (1993) , 13 patients underwent intra-oral reconstruction using the jejunum free flap or radial forearm flap. The choice of intra-oral reconstruction with jejunum free flap was related to the dimension of the superficial defect and the general health of the patient. The free radial forearm flap was generally used for the elderly with poor general condition. The authors report their experience. The rectus abdominis myocutaneous flap consists of a skin paddle, anterior rectus sheath, rectus abdominis and deep inferior epigastric artery and veins. Thickness of skin paddle, anterior rectus sheath and volume of rectus muscle can be adjusted appropriately to accommodate the needs. Various designs of this flap are available and they can classified into the following four basic patterns; Pattern I (Pectoralis major flap type), Pattern II (Extended type), Pattern III (Muscle diminished flap) and Pattern IV (Skin thinning type). Combinations of these patterns are also possible. Eighteen patients underwent oral and maxillofacial reconstruction after tumor ablation using the rectus abdominis myocutaneous flap. Ten cases of tongue defect, two cases of hemifacial contour deficiency, two oropharyneal defects, two cheek defects including buccal mucosa, and one lower gingiva and hard and soft palate defect. In this series, there were seven cases of Pattern I, three Pattern II, three Pattern III and five combinations of Patterns III and IV. It can be concluded that the rectus abdominis myocutaneous flap in a very reliable flap for oral and maxillofacial reconstruction. An overall of 53 from 565 transplants (9.4 %) suffered from circulatory disorders. There was a significant influence on transplant perfusion by abuse of alcohol, liver diseases, lung diseases and diabetes mellitus. Due to intervention in right time, 30 transplants could be saved while 23 microsurgical (5.2%) and 3 pedicled (2.5%) transplants could not be saved. Circulatory disorders of microsurgical transplants appeared in only 4.8 % of non smokers whilst it appeared in smokers in 15.6%, in patients with coronary heart diseases in 16.6 % and in patients with lung diseases in 23.3 %. Preoperative irradiation had no significant influence on transplant circulation. Nevertheless, with a higher irradiation dose a rise of prolongued wound healing, dehiscents and infections appeared. Jejunal transplants showed lower reactivity than myocutaneous flaps, i.e. at doses of more than 60 Gys, wound healing disorders of jejunal transplants appeared in 15.4 %, since they appeared in 34.6% of myocutaneous flaps. Pedicled flaps showed a higher rate of wound healing disorders with liver-and lung diseases (32.2%) than microsurgical transplants (11.9 %). The donor sites showed similar results. Liver diseases and diabetes mellitus were associated with a significant rise of wound healing disorders after harvest of myocutaneous flaps.
body_text.section: Department of Maxillofacial Surgery, University of Rome 'La Sapienza', Italy

body_text.text: The radial forearm flap is often the flap of choice in reconstruction following extensive tissue loss in the head and neck. However, there are currently no published detailed prospective studies of the associated donor site morbidity.
body_text.section: Reg. Maxillofacial Unit, Walton Hospital, Liverpool, UK

body_text.text: Fifty patients have been examined pre-and postoperatively in order to assess donor site morbidity. Assessment included Allen test, Doppler pressures, forearm circumference, grip strength, wrist movement, size of grafted area, sensory changes and the patient's subjective assessment of forearm function. Complications of wound healing and pathological fracture of the radius in the composite group were recorded.
body_text.section: Reg. Maxillofacial Unit, Walton Hospital, Liverpool, UK

body_text.text: Complications found were skin graft loss (25 %) tendon exposure (7 %) and delayed healing of split graft donor sites (13 %), Pathological fracture of the radius occurred in 19 % of composite flaps. At one year donor arm function was restricted in approximately 20 % of these patients, nearly all having had composite flaps.

body_text.text: The causes of these problems and their clinical implications will be discussed.

body_text.text: Reconstruction of the nasal area after ablative surgery for tumors still remains a challenge for the OMF surgeon. This presentation deals with our experience with 136 cases in which various techniques were used. Indications, advantages and disadvantages of the various alternatives will be discussed.
body_text.section: Dept. of OMF Surgery, Barcelona University, Lerida, Spain

body_text.text: Tumor caused partial loss of the tongue, floor of the mouth and the alveolar crest is connected with far-reaching limitation of function, such as articulation, phonation and chewing. Insertion of endosseous dental implants enables adequate rehabilitation of these patients, From 1988 to 1994 37 patients with tumor caused partial loss of the mandible have been supplied with t62 implants (Bone-Lock, Leibinger, D-Freiburg) for final rehabilitation. In 25 patients a preoperative combined irradiation and chemotherapy was given. After tumor resection and partial resection of the mandible 23 patients have been supplied with a microsurgical revascularized small bowel transplant, 3 with a flap from pectoralis major muscle and 1 patient with a flap from the latissimus dorsi muscle to cover the intraoral defect. 31 patients have been reconstructed with autologous bone grafts (26 x free non-revascularized iliac crest, 5 x microsurgical revascularized scapula, 1 x free rib). The time between tumor operation and reconstruction amounted to 22 months average and between reconstruction and insertion of implants 15 months on average. In one case we achieved reconstruction and implantation simultaneously. 21 to the 162 inserted implants had to be removed, 4 implants could not be integrated into the prosthetic suprastructure because of unfavourable localisation (success rate 88.7 %). 2 patients (8 implants) had to be counted as a drop-out. 25 patients are finally supplied with an overdenture. Parameters of the periimplant gingiva of tumor patients like Hygiene-Index, Gingiva-Index, Sulcus-Bleeding-Index and pocket-provingdepth showed significant worse results in comparison with non tumor patients. Periimplant bone resorption however progressed significant slower. From a subjective and objective point of view functional rehabilitation of tumor patients with dental implants is often limited, for aesthetic and social rehabilitation, however, it gains outstanding importance.
body_text.section: Dept. of OMF Surgery, University of Wiirzburg, Germany

body_text.text: Dept. of Maxillofacial and Plastic Surgery, St. James's Hospital, Dublin, Ireland Since January 1990 endosseous implants have been inserted in irradiated mandibles. The implants have been used directly in irradiated bone as well as in bone irradiated at lower dose outside the centre of radiation, as well as in bone grafts in areas previously irradiated. In 16 patients, 72 endosseous IMZ-implants have been inserted. The post operative course of 10 implants could not be further evaluated because the patients passed away. Two implants had to be removed because of tumor recurrence. Four implants had to be removed because of lack of integration.

P The introduction of adequate internal fixation by means of screws and plates and the better understanding of the healing pattern of bone under different conditions has tremendously changed our treatment approach, not only in general but especially in relation to acutely and chronically infected fractures. While until a few years ago in acutely infected fractures the first treatment steps were drainage, antibiotics and intermaxillary fixation or external pin fixation, today our approach is immediate, adequate stable internal fixation with plates and screws together with drainage and antibiotics. This treatment approach is especially helpful in view of the rising number of uncooperative patients like in geriatrics or alcoholics and drug addicts. This kind of treatment is very cost effective although at first glance it may not appear to be that way. During this presentation we will present our experience over the last 10 years. The technical background of the operative procedure is explained, the question of immediate bone grafting is discussed and a statistical overview is presented.

body_text.text: A prospective one year study was undertaken to document the incidence of concomitant fracture of the cervical spine with facial fractures. A total of 582 consecutive patients with facial fractures referred to the National Referral Centre at St. James's Hospital (from 1 January 1992 to 31 December 1992) were included in this study. 1.04 % (n = 6) of patients were found to have an associated cervical spine injury. All of the cervical injuries occurred in the subgroup of patients with facial trauma following road traffic accidents (n = 94)~ resulting in an incidence in this subgroup of 6.1%. All 6 patients had multiple injuries and facial lacerations and 5 had mandibular fractures. All 5 conscious patients complained of neck stiffness or pain. Only 2 of the six cervical fractures were observed on standard three-view plain cervical radiographs (two fractures of C2). Both these fractures were seen on computed tomography (CT) with two further fractures (body of C4 and body of C7). Two patients had fractures that were diagnosable only on stress views under radiographic screening (subluxations of C4/C5 and C5/C6). This study illustrates the need for a high index of suspicion of associated cervical injury in patients with facial fractures, especially following high velocity type injury. It also illustrates that negative plain radiographs may require further radiographic investigation (CT or stress views) and it high-lights the limitations of CT in the diagnosis of ligamentous injury of the cervical spine where stress views under radiographic screening of the spine are of value.
body_text.section: References

body_text.text: Sinai Hospital and Univ. of Detroit School of Dentistry, Detroit, Michigan, USA This review catalogues not only the types of injuries and the frequency of different treatment modalities in the management of patients with traumatic injuries received at Sinai Hospital of Detroit between 1985 and 1993 but discusses, too, logistical considerations such as time between injury and delivery to the emergency service, fidelity of patients to their postoperative regimens, and the uncertainty as to final disposition of the patients in many cases. The data base was derived from the records of approx. 1200 patients, of which some 350 provided information consistent enough for inclusion. Differences in the types and numbers of injuries within 3 distinct metropolitan ethnic groups are outlined. The presentation reports a computerised factoring of patients in terms of topographical distribution of wounds, types of tissues injured, the evaluative and therapeutic details of management but stresses equally much the social factors which influence the outcomes of treatment.
body_text.section: R. B. Macintosh

body_text.text: Ashraf Ayoub, Terry Philiben, William Hislop, Martin Cope Dept. of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Canniesburn Hospital and Glasgow Dental Hosp. and School, Glasgow University, Scotland, UK This study was carried out to assess the results of treating malar fractures in the West of Scotland over the last 10 years.

cite_spans.text: Terry Philiben, William Hislop, Martin Cope Dept. of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Canniesburn Hospital and Glasgow Dental Hosp. and School, Glasgow University, Scotland, UK

body_text.section: An Analysis of 1200 Cases of Malar Fracture (A Retrospective Study)

body_text.text: A ten year review of 1200 cases of malar fractures treated at Canniesburn Hospital, in the West of Scotland Regional Maxillofacial Unit, from 1983 to 1993, is presented. The following parameters were studied; age and sex distribution, type of fracture, treatment modalities, methods of fixation and altered sensation in the infra orbital nerve distribution. A Gillies incision was the commonest surgical approach used to reduce the fractured malar. This was followed by fixation frequently with transnasal Kirschner wires. In the majority of unstable cases internal fixation was applied using bone plates at the fronto-zygomatic suture and/or at the zygomatic buttress. Silicone rubber sheeting was used to support the herniated orbital contents in blow out fracture. The methods used for assessment of infra orbital sensory disturbance are presented. The relationship between alteration of sensation and methods of fixation is discussed.
body_text.section: An Analysis of 1200 Cases of Malar Fracture (A Retrospective Study)

body_text.text: During the Afghan war, initially a conservative concept in the surgical management of gunshot injuries of the mandible was adopted .
body_text.section: Department of Surgical Stomatology Propaedeutics, Moscow Medical Stomatologycal Institute

body_text.text: Thorough analysis of 200 files of injured patients showed that conservative management of the fractures, however, resulted in 44.3 % of patients with inflammation which in turn resulted in osteomyelitis in 34.3%. 22.0% of the patients consequently had bony defects. Based on this analysis we changed to a radical surgical management of mandible fractures caused by gunshots. The treatment consists of: 1) Removal of all bony fragments 2) Extensive excision of wound margins 3) Cleaning the mandibular fragments till capillary bleeding was seen 4) Attaching the mandibular fragments or bring them closer to each other.
body_text.section: Department of Surgical Stomatology Propaedeutics, Moscow Medical Stomatologycal Institute

body_text.text: In order to eliminate combined hard and soft tissue defects we used a special device called compressiondistraction apparatus (CDA).
body_text.section: Department of Surgical Stomatology Propaedeutics, Moscow Medical Stomatologycal Institute

body_text.text: Five different methods of osteoplasty were used, which made simultaneous restitution of the combined tissue defects possible.
body_text.section: Department of Surgical Stomatology Propaedeutics, Moscow Medical Stomatologycal Institute

body_text.text: The radical surgical management of 130 patients with mandible fractures caused by gunshots resulted in a considerable decrease of infection, and an almost complete elimination of osteomyelitis. Good functional and aesthetic results were obtained in all 42 patients, having mandibular defects varying from 2 to 15 cm length. The methods can be used in patients with different mandibular defects of any origin.
body_text.section: Department of Surgical Stomatology Propaedeutics, Moscow Medical Stomatologycal Institute

body_text.text: Severe maxillofacial trauma accompanied by a displaced ethmoidal complex fracture was confirmed by CT imaging in 40 adult patients. Routine surgical management included reduction of fractures, miniplate fixation and interosseous wiring. The fractured ethmoidal cell system was left to heal spontaneously. A follow-up including endoscopy of the nasal cavity as well as rhinomanometry and computed tomography was carried out 24 months after surgery. The ethmoidal cell system showed a clear tendency to spontaneous reventilation and drainage. Routine debridement of every ethmoidal cell system does not appear to be necessary. Patients with severe nasoethmoidal fractures should undergo rhinological follow-up examination including CT imaging, approximately 3 months after surgery. In our cases, we saw frontal sinus mucositis, traumatic mucoceles and paranasal sinusitis.
body_text.section: Department of Surgical Stomatology Propaedeutics, Moscow Medical Stomatologycal Institute

body_text.text: Nineteen patients with post traumatic defects of the mandible varying from 1 to 13 cm were subject of this study. A compression-distraction device was used as developed in our institution.
body_text.section: Medical Institute Arkhangelsk, Arkhangelsk, Russia

body_text.text: The technique allows for adequate compression and distraction up to periods of 6 months. On average, distraction was carried out for periods of 2.5-4.5 months depending on the needs. The amount of distraction also varied but was never more than 1 ram/day. Clinical and radiographic pictures will be shown to illustrate the technique.
body_text.section: Medical Institute Arkhangelsk, Arkhangelsk, Russia

body_text.text: The aim of the present study is to analyse the role of the growing mandible and the dental development on the pattern of fractures as seen in children. 157 pediatric patients with a total of mandibular fractures were evaluated retrospectively. All patients had been examined with the aid of orthopantomography. The patients were divided into four age groups according to the development of the dentition (group A: 0-5 years, B: 64 years, C: 10-12 years, and D: 13-15 years). A majority of the children (72%) had fractures in the condylar region. Bicycle accidents and falls were the two main causes in all age groups. However, there were significant differences in the causes and location of the fractures between groups A + B and C + D. The proportion of condylar fractures decreased and the proportion of body and angle fractures increased with increasing age; fractures in the horizontal part of the mandible were mainly observed in groups C and D. Both etiological factors and fracture patterns in the patients older than 10 years of age resembled those of adults. The differences observed should be taken into consideration in studies concerning mandibular fractures in pediatric patients.
body_text.section: Dept. of OMF Surgery, University of Helsinki, Finland

body_text.text: The management of triangular fragments in the lower border of the mandible constitutes a problem for the oral and maxillofacial surgeon. The literature is unclear as to whether it is preferable to perform an open reduction and fix the fragment or to leave it untreated in order to preserve the periosteum and the vascularisation.
body_text.section: Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Sheba Medical Center, Tel Hashomer, Israel

body_text.text: The purpose of this presentation is to discuss the issue of management of triangular fragments in the lower border of the mandible and to propose a policy for their management. Twenty five cases of mandibular fractures with triangular fragments in the lower border were retrospectively analysed with regard to mode of treatment and infection rate. All patients had comminuted fractures to the oral cavity.
body_text.section: Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Sheba Medical Center, Tel Hashomer, Israel

body_text.text: The analysis showed that patients with fragments which remained untreated had no complications, whereas more than 50% of the cases in which the fragments were repositioned and fixed became infected. The complexity of the management of these fragments will be discussed. Our results indicate that there is possible benefit of leaving triangular fragments untreated.
body_text.section: Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Sheba Medical Center, Tel Hashomer, Israel

Vukelic-Markovic Clinic for Maxillofacial Surgery, Military Medical Academy, Belgrado, Yugoslavia In the period 1991-1993, 251 patients with predominantly maxillofacial injuries were managed in our department. Twenty-six had facial palsy. After adequate, clinical, radiographic and functional examination, treatment was begun which consisted of exploration and freeing of the nerve from fibrous tissue (3 x ), micro-surgical reconstruction using the greater auricular nerve (2 x ), direct microsurgical suturing(1 x ), decompression of the temporal bone (9 x ) and conservative means, i.e. corticosteroids, Vit. B, and vasodilatators (11 x ). All patients underwent physical therapy as well.

body_text.section: Facial Nerve Injuries in Patients with Head and Neck War Injuries

body_text.text: Facial palsy is a common feature in patients with head and neck war injuries. The causative factor, however, differs from patient to patient. Proper treatment can only be instituted after careful evaluation of the signs and symptoms.
body_text.section: Facial Nerve Injuries in Patients with Head and Neck War Injuries

body_text.text: Changes in the period of hospitalisation required for patients with fractures of the maxillofacial skeleton were examined by means of a comparative longitudinal study of two series of patients, treated by the Oral and Maxillofacial Surgical Unit of the University Hospital Nijmegen. The study spans the periods 1 January 1960 to 31 December 1974 ('first period' with 1379 patients) and 1 January 1975 to 31 December 1987 (' second period' with 1324 patients). In the second period the number of patients discharged from hospital in the first week after hospitalisation nearly doubled (60%) as compared to the first period (33 %). After two weeks these figures increased to 81% and 63 % respectively. In the second period the average duration of hospitalisation is significantly less. This important reduction in the number of days spent in the hospital can be explained by:
body_text.section: Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, University Hospital Nijmegen, The Netherlands

body_text.text: -changes in the aetiology of maxillofacial fractures -changes in the treatment of multitraumatized patients -changes in the treatment of maxillofacial fractures -changes in the antibiotic treatment regime -changes in the area that drains it's traumatology to our hospital.
body_text.section: Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, University Hospital Nijmegen, The Netherlands

body_text.text: The above findings cannot be compared with other data because this type of information has not been found in the literature. In view of the fact that financing of health care becomes an increasingly important social and political problem, not only in the Netherlands but also in other European countries, data concerning the period of hospitalisation of maxillofacial trauma patients are important.
body_text.section: Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, University Hospital Nijmegen, The Netherlands

body_text.text: The most serious immediate life threatening complication following maxillofacial trauma is airway obstruction. Endotracheal intubation and tracheostomy or cricothyroidectomy are the principle ways for securing the airway. Indications for surgical securing of the airway have changed in recent years. Important factors which have brought about those changes were the design and material used in the construction of endotracheal tubes and the use of rigid internal fixation as a common practice in the treatment of fractures of the facial skeleton.
body_text.section: Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Sheba Medical Center, Tel Hashomer, Israel

body_text.text: The purpose of this presentation is to review and evaluate the experience accumulated in our department in treating airway complications following maxillofacial trauma. The studygroup comprised of 599 patients with maxillofacial fractures treated in our department between the years 1985-1992. Out of these patients, 13 required tracheostorny. Of these, 6 patients had cricothyroidectomy on arrival. Of the remaining 7 patients, 3 required tracheostomy because of airway obstruction, 3 due to respiratory distress, and 1 due to difficulty in intubation. The other 586 patients maintained free airway and non of them developed a late airway obstruction. We conclude that surgical securing of the airway may play an important role in the overall management of patients with facial trauma. The choice of surgical securing of the airway, versus endotracheal intubation is an individual one. In view of the improved endotracheal intubation techniques and the use of rigid internal fixation for the treatment of facial fractures, the need for surgical procedures to secure the airway is not as common as in the past.
body_text.section: Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Sheba Medical Center, Tel Hashomer, Israel

body_text.text: Lambros Zouloumis, Nikos Lazaridis, Savas lordanidis
body_text.section: The Use of Dumbach Titan-Mesh-System in Defects of the Middle Third of the Face

body_text.text: Despite the increasing use of titanium mesh osteosynthesis for trauma, orthognathic and reconstructive surgery in the USA, it is only in recent years that it has gained acceptance in Europe.
body_text.section: Dept. Oral-Maxillofacial Surg., Aristotle University, Thessaloniki, Greece

body_text.text: This paper appraises the Dumbach Titan-Mesh-(DTM) System in the periorbital and other regions. Since June 1990 the DTM system has been in use in our Unit. The adaptability of the DTM system has allowed us to use it in a wide range of cranio-maxillofacial procedures including: a) At the fronto-zygomatic suture and infra orbital rim inzygoma fractures. b) Depressed or comminuted fractures of the anterior wall of the frontal sinus c) Reconstruction of the orbital floor in case of defects. d) Reconstruction after tumor resection of the part of the malar region. e) Comminuted fractures of the zygomatic arch. This system has been found to be quick and reliable. The mesh is highly adaptable. We present a variety of cases where we have been using this system. The results after 1 to 4 years follow-up are satisfactory and we did not observe any complication, and none of our patients demanded to remove the T-mesh-panel or complained of any other symptoms.
body_text.section: Dept. Oral-Maxillofacial Surg., Aristotle University, Thessaloniki, Greece

body_text.text: Fractures of the orbital roof are not frequently seen. They occur either as isolated fractures or in conjunction with other fractures of the orbital wall, frontal bone and zygomatic bone. Orbital roof fractures can be nondisplaced or they might be displaced intra-cranially or intraorbitally. The signs and symptoms related to those fractures depend upon the direction of displacement.
body_text.section: Dept. of Maxillofacial Surgery, Military Hosp. Riyadh, Saudi Arabia

body_text.text: The diagnosis of orbital roof fractures is based on clinical examination, conventional radiography and computerised tomography. The management of orbital roof fractures depends on the degree of bone displacement and on the clinical manifestation. Displaced fractures need surgical reduction and fixation. Complications of orbital roof fractures are related to possible brain-or eye-damage.
body_text.section: Dept. of Maxillofacial Surgery, Military Hosp. Riyadh, Saudi Arabia

body_text.text: In this presentation the aetiology of orbital roof fractures is discussed and the diagnosis and management of 15 patients are presented.
body_text.section: Dept. of Maxillofacial Surgery, Military Hosp. Riyadh, Saudi Arabia

body_text.text: This presentation deals with the use of rigid plate fixation for patients with non-healed mandibular fractures. The results of this treatment on a group of 26 patients with nonunion will be presented. Six of these patients had osteomyelitis, 19 had pseudoarthrosis and in one patient an osteotomy had to be carried out to align the fragments in a proper way. The author concludes that rigid fixation is extremely useful for patients with non-healing fractures.
body_text.section: Dept. of OMF Surgery, Plodiv, Bulgaria

body_text.text: During the period 1973 1992, 6197 patients with fractures of the mandible have been treated in the Dept. of OMF Surgery at Kaunas Medical Academy. The fractures were located in various areas: 73.1% in the mandibular body, including angle, 10.5 % in the ascending ramus, 14.9 % were located in both the body and ascending ramus. Multiple mandibular fractures occurred in 1.7% of the patients. There were 5323 (85.9 %) males involved and 874 (14.1%) females. The fractures were diagnosed using radiographs and in some cases echography and sonography was utilised. Most patients were treated using conservative methods i.e. arch bars and intermaxillary fixation (IMF) (80.1%). In 5.3 % osteosynthesis was used and in 14.6 % combined use of osteosynthesis and IMF was utiiised. Most patients were hospitalised for approximately 12 days after which they were followed-up in the out-patient clinic.
body_text.section: Dept. of OMF Surgery, Kaunas, Lithuania

body_text.text: Long term follow-up of patients with craniofacial fractures is rarely reported in the literature. From 1990 to 1993, we treated six patients with late and very late complications of craniofacial fractures including chronic infections, fistulae and osteitis. Follow-up from initial treatment ranged from 5 to 15 years (mean 8.5 years). Detailed medical histories revealed the persistence of a communication between nasal, ethrnoidal or frontal sinus cavities and the skull base in all cases, Treatment was performed in two stages: 1. Removal of all inflamed tissue, closure of the cutaneous defects and complete isolation of the skull base from the facial cavities; and 2. Reconstruction of the cranial vault 6 months later. Post-operative results were satisfactory and folIow-up uneventful (mean 18 months).
body_text.section: Dept. of Plastic and Maxillo-Facial Surgery, Foeh Hospital, Paris, France

body_text.text: Late complications of craniofacial fractures present a significant challenge to the maxillofacial surgeon. The authors conclude that such complications can be avoided at initial treatment.
body_text.section: Dept. of Plastic and Maxillo-Facial Surgery, Foeh Hospital, Paris, France

body_text.text: During the period 1991-1993, 677 patients with fractures of the mandibular angle were treated in our unit. Closed reduction with IMF was used in 158 patients. In 363 patients a Kirchner wire was used along with IMF. In 48 patients wire osteosyntheses were applied and in the remaining 108 patients miniplates.
body_text.section: Dept. of OMF Surgery, Riga, Latvia

body_text.text: Disturbed healing and infection occurred in: 5.4 % of the IMF cases only, 4 % of the patients with Kirchner wire and IMF, 6.4 % of the patients treated with wire osteosynthesis and 2.3 % of the cases treated with miniplates.
body_text.section: Dept. of OMF Surgery, Riga, Latvia

body_text.text: Surgical correction of transverse discrepancies of the maxilla may be necessary in cases where the arch form is too wide , too narrow or asymmetrical in order to avoid crossbites, which may occur uni-or bilaterally. There are several causes for the presence of transverse discrepancies including: developmental deformities, postraumatic situations, scar contraction as in cleft palate patients. In most of these cases malocclusion is the result sometimes giving rise to functional problems. The correction of transverse discrepancies depends on the localisation and the severity of the deformity in the maxillary arch. Simple discrepancies can be corrected orthodontically, sometimes after surgically assisted expansion. Unilateral deformities are best corrected by hemimaxillary osteotomies, with a high relapse tendency being considered in cases of cleft palate deformities. Bilateral transverse discrepancies of the anterior part of the maxilla with widening or narrowing of the alveolar arch can be treated by anterior maxillary osteotomies. body_text.text: The objective of this investigation was to characterise the postoperative wound-healing impairments observed, using a retrospective evaluation of 636 dysgnathic patients on whom an orthodontic operation with varying perioperative antibiotic regimes had been carried out between 1981 and 1992. Data from 438 female and 198 male patients with an average age of 27.0 years were available and statistically evaluated on a survey form that included 78 parameters. Altogether 134 maxillary, 313 mandibular and 189 combined maxillary/mandibular osteotomies were carried out, whereby Cefotaxim (74.4%), Cefamandol (10.8%), Ceftriaxon (5.4%), Cefotiam (2.8%) Piperacillin (2.7%) and others (3.9 %) were administrated perioperatively. Shortterm prophylaxis (with an antibiotic dose of 48 h) was carried out in 48.4 % of the patients, long-term prophylaxis with an average duration of 6.0 d in 51.6%. Wound dehiscences were found in 8.9% of all operations and wound infections with established pus secretion in 3.1%. Wound infections were observed in only 1.5% of the maxillary osteotomies, but in 4.8 % of the mandibular osteotomies and in 1.6 % of the combined operations. The antibiotic selection as well as antibiotic dosage duration did not have any significant influence. Only subsequent to mandibular osteotomies did a significantly higher number of wound infections occur because of wound dehiscences. The wound dehiscence rate proved to be both dependent on the method of operation as well as on its extent, as 12.2% of the combined maxillary/mandibular osteotomies revealed dehiscences while only 5.1% of the mandibular osteotomies had wound dehiscences. As the results of Singer (1983) , Balan (1984) and Mfihling et. al. (1984) have shown, the low infection rate in this investigation confirms the effectiveness of a perioperative antibiotic treatment. Since the infection rate cannot be additionally reduced by longterm prophylaxis, but rather the appearance of resistant micro flora is encouraged, we consider short-term perioperative treatment of 48 h the method of choice.

body_text.text: Clinical assessment consisted of examination under endotracheal anaesthesia, radiological assessment consisted of axial contrast CT Scanning at 5 mm intervals. Clinical assessment had a sensitivity of 73 % and a specificity of 69 %, twenty three (45 %) of the 51 histologically positive necks had been assessed as negative both clinically and radiologically. Micrometastases and metastasis to nodes of less than 1.5 cm accounted for 16 of the 21 false-negative assessments. Three (4%) of the 85 histologically negative necks had been assessed as positive both clinically and radiologically; eight (9 %) had been assessed as positive clinically, and a further eight (9%) radiologically. body_text.text: Irradiation mucositis is an inflammatory-like process of the oropharyngeal mucosa following therapeutic irradiation of patients who have head-neck cancer. Mucositis is often dose-limiting, and may thus have a negative effect on curative cancer treatment. It has been reported that aerobic Gram-negative bacilli can aggravate mucositis. It is also known that 0.1% chlorhexidine rinses were neither successful in controlling Gram-negative bacilli nor in reducing mucositis. This prospective, randomised controlled study reports the effect of PTA-lozenges containing 2 mg polymyxin E, 1.8 mg tobramycin and 10 mg amphotericin B on the prevention of mucositis. The PTA-lozenges were prescribed four times daily, starting on the first day of irradiation. The results in 15 comparably irradiated patients using PTA-lozenges were evaluated by comparing with 2 groups of 15 patients rinsing with chlorhexidine 0.1% or placebo. Eradication of Gram-negative bacilli and yeasts was achieved within 3 weeks in the PTA-group, whereas no effect on these flora was determined in the chlorhexidine and placebo group (pFCX A0.01, student t-test). The severity and extent of mucositis was reduced in PTA-lozenges group as compared to the other two groups (p < 0.05, student ttest). All patients in the PTA-group showed erythema only. In both the chlorhexidine and placebo rinsing group 80 % suffered severe mucositis with extended pseudo membranes. In all PTA-lozenges patients no nasogastric tube feedings were needed as compared to 30 % in the other groups (p < 0.01, student t-test).
body_text.section: Dept. of Oral & Maxillofacial Surgery, University Hospital Groningen, The Netherlands

body_text.text: Conclusion: Selective elimination of Gram-negative bacilli by PTA-lozenges prevents severe mucositis and is a step forward in the management of oral sequelae in the irradiated head-neck cancer patient.

body_text.text: * Dept. of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Hannover Medical School, Germany, ** Dept. of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, University of Kiel, Germany Metastases from malignant tumors to the head and neck are seldomly seen. According to Meyer and Shklar (1965) they represent only 1% of all oral malignancies. Metastatic neoplasms are usually intraosseous, with most of them occurring in the mandible. Major symptoms of metastatic tumors requiring further diagnostic interventions are pain, swelling, bleeding and ulceration and neurological disturbances. We report our experience with 30 patients with metastatic tumors in the head and neck region seen in the period from 1980 to 1993. There were 17 males and 13 females ranging in age from 29 to 89 years (median age 64 years). Metastatic tumors were localised as follows: mandible (16), maxilla (5), soft tissue (7) and maxillary sinus (2). Metastases originated from primary tumors of different location, with breast carcinoma (6) being the most frequently reported tumor. In the majority of cases palliative therapy including surgery as well as chemo-and radiotherapy is the treatment of choice. Even in a palliative setting surgical interventions including mandibular resection and functional reconstruction is warranted. A close interdisciplinary management of these patients is mandatory.

body_text.section: Anastomosis of Small Vessels with High Calibre Discrepancy Using a New Resorbable Device

body_text.text: The anastomosis of small vessels with sutures is time consuming and requires continuous training on the part of the surgeon. To simplify this procedure several so-called mechanic anastomotic devices have been developed. Although joining two vessels of markedly different diameters is often a fact in the clinical situation, none of these anastomotic systems seem to be designed to cope with this fact. The presented system can be used to connect vessels with high calibre discrepancy. The system is resorbable and consists of a cuff and a shrinkable sleeve. The 'shrinkingfeature' of the cuff allows a high adaptability to the various diameters. To carry out the anastomosis the vessel end with the smaller diameter is pulled through the cuff and everted over it. The sleeve is pulled over the end of the larger vessel, and this vessel is then slipped over the everted smaller vessel.

body_text.text: The sleeve is made to shrink, forcing the lumen of the larger vessel onto the everted vessel and its cuff. The time needed for this procedure was less than 5 minutes in rabbit vessels of diameters 1.0 mm to 4.0 mm with discrepancies of 1.0 mm to 2.0mm. The patency rate one hour after the procedure was 100%. If the results of the animal experimental investigations currently under way confirm these results, clinical use of the system is planned.

body_text.text: Pseudoankylosis of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ) is a persistent restricted mandibular mobility caused by a myogenic, osteogenic or neurogenic condition outside the TMJ. Surgical treatment of this condition is often indicated when the patient complains of functional or related psychosocial impairment, such as a reduced chewing ability, social restrictions (a.o. eating with small cutlery, kissing problems), and hampered dental care and oral hygiene. The aim of this study was to describe the diagnostic procedures, treatment planning, surgical technique and post-operative care in patients suffering from pseudoankylosis. In six patients (1 female, 5 male; mean age 23_+7 years, range 15-33 years) TMJ pseudoankylosis was treated by unilateral (2 cases) or bilateral (4 case) coronoidectomy. Post-operative physical therapy was applied on a daily basis for the first week and continued once per week for at least 3 weeks. In 3 cases a dynamic bite opener was used. The results show that radiological screening with CT or MRI was always needed to differentiate between intra-and extra-capsular TMJ ankylosis in addition to clinical examination and conventional plain radiography. In one case examination under general anaesthesia had to be performed to assure the diagnosis. In all cases coronoidectomy was preferred to myotomy or brisement forc6, because of the change to create again fibrosis. Maximum mouthopening increased from 15_+ 7 mm preoperatively to 41 + 10 mm six months postoperatively (p < 0.01, paired t-test). This study shows that dissection of the coronoid process is a reliable method to release pseudoankylosis if immediate postoperative physical therapy is instituted.

body_text.text: Between March 1992 and March 1993, 40 carcinoma patients with suspicious involvement of the mandible underwent partial surgical resection of the lower jaw. The results were recorded and analysed with the aid of the integrated statistical and graphic analysing system RS/1. The use of logistic regression analysis and discriminant analysis showed that a combination of clinical evaluation and panoramic radiography revealed the statistically best prognosis of a bony involvement (1/17 false-negative, 5/23 false-positive results). The combination of panoramic radiography and ultrasonography showed similar good results. Conventional tomography, HRCT and SPECT seem to improve the statistical prognosis of a bony involvement only in individual cases.

HBO increases the oxygen available to hypoxic or anoxic tissue. Furthermore, HBO enhances healing by inducing fibroblastic proliferation and capillary formation in bone and soft tissue. During the period 1981-1991 we used a monoplace hyperbaric chamber and since 1992 a multiplace hyperbaric chamber for HBO treatments. HBO was given at 2.5-2.8 ATA for 90 -120 minutes, once per day. In the present series altogether 18 patients suffering from osteoradionecrosis of the mandible or maxilla were treated with surgery and HBO. The surgical therapy consisted of decortication of the infected bone whereafter this bone area was covered with a free periosteal transplant from the tibia. The shortest follow up time is now over 9 months and 17 of the 18 patients treated are free of symptoms. We conclude that HBO-therapy is a promising adjunctive method to surgery in the treatment of mandibular or maxillary osteoradionecrosis.

Angelopoulos Dept. of MF Surgery and Ophthalmology, Greek Anticancer Institute, University of Athens, Greece Malignant tumors of the orbit and the orbitomaxillary area are relatively uncommon constituting less than 10 % of head and neck malignancies. Their management often requires extensive mutilating procedures and poses diverse problems with regard to reconstruction. During the years 1990-1993, 35 patients with orbitomaxillary and orbital malignancies were treated surgically. Tumors arose from the lids, the globe or some part of the orbital contents or invaded the orbit from the maxillary antrum or the ethmoids. Surgical treatment varied from simple orbital exenteration, exenteration to include the eyelids and the skin of the eyebrow, to hemimaxillectomies with orbital exenteration and nasoorbital-cranial approaches. Immediate reconstruction followed in all cases and included skin grafting and the use of median forehead and temporalis flaps. There were no intraor immediate post-operative deaths. Twenty patients were treated with post-operative radiotherapy and 5 with radiotherapy and chemotherapy. Tumors recurred in 10 cases that received additional palliative treatment only. Recurrences occurred during the first post-operative year. Seven patients died from distant metastases or intracranial involvement. Diagnostic methods and prognostic criteria are presented and the reconstructive procedures are discussed. It is concluded that except from broad guidelines that determine the operability of the tumors, the surgical treatment of orbital and orbitomaxillary malignancies should be individualised. body_text.text: We report on 10 patients with primary and secondary reconstruction of large bony defects after tumor surgery. Resection of bone was carried out because of squamous cell carcinoma in 6 patients, the remaining 4 patients suffered from solid carcinoma, solitary plasmocytoma, osteosarcoma, melanoma. Two patients underwent primary reconstruction, in 8 patients the reconstruction was done secondarily, 1 to 5 years after tumor surgery. All patients were treated with preoperative radiation and/or chemotherapy. The 3-D models of the skull were produced by laserlithography. For the bony reconstruction 8 iliac crest, 1 fibular and 1 scapular grafts were used. In order to outline the advantages of the preoperative model planning, 2 groups could be defined. In primary reconstruction the design and adaptation of the osteosynthesis material would have been difficult when the tumor was located in the bone and would have led to deformation of the bony contours. In case of secondary reconstruction the dislocated resection stumps of the mandible could be well assessed. Preoperative model surgery made it possible to redefine the correct midline, and to reposition the displaced condyles. This allowed a exact preoperative design of the osteosynthesis material and a perfect calculation of the size and configuration of the bone graft. In conclusion, preoperative model surgery facilitated the surgical management and proved to be a time saving factor in these patients.

body_text.text: The temporalis muscle has been widely used as pedicled flap for oral reconstruction. The uncovered myofascial flap undergoes a gradual healing process with its oral surface eventually being replaced by mucosa. However, the origin of the epithelial cells initiating the healing process and the nature of the epithelialization of the flap remains unknown. The objective of this study is to elucidate the factors involved in this epithelialization process. 32 cats have undergone partial maxillectomy and immediate reconstruction with temporalis myofascial flap. They were sacrificed at defined post-surgical intervals of 2, 4, 6, 8, 12, 14, 18 and 24 weeks. The reconstructed maxillae were analysed in 8 cats by a combination of light microscopy and scanning electron microscopy. All cats had uncomplicated healing of the flaps and the reconstructed palate was eventually lined with a smooth mucosa without rugae at 24 weeks. The epithelialization process was found to be initiated from the wound margins and the neo-epithelial cells advanced over the granulating myofascial surface with eventual coverage of the whole flap. No nidus of epithelial cells was noted on the granulating surface. The regenerated mucosa was parakeratinised stratified squamous epithelium with a distinct ultra-surface feature, which is quite different from the normal palate. In conclusion, the healing of the temporalis myofascial flap in the mouth is by secondary intention rather than by shedded mucosal cells with multifocal epithelialization.

Kriimer Dept. of OMF Surgery, University of K6ln, Germany Hyperplastic lesions of the oral mucosa such as leukoplakia and oral lichen planus can eventually develop into squamous cell carcinomas (SCC) and provide an excellent model for multistage carcinogenesis. The development of carcinomas is assumed to be in part the result of genetic changes. Mutations of the tumor suppressor genes p53 en Rb are the most common genetic changes in human solid tumors. It has recently been shown that p53 transcription can also be inhibited by the MDM2 protein. Furthermore, p53 plays an important role in the cell cycle and new therapeutic approaches for p53 deficient tumors now seem to become feasible. The purpose of this study was, therefore, to determine the role of alterations of the tumor suppressor genes p53 and Rb as well as the expression of mdm2 in the carcinogenesis in the oral mucosa.

body_text.text: We investigated p53, Rb and mdm2-expression in 256 tissue sections of normal mucosa, pre malignant, malignant and metastatic lesions of the oral mucosa as well as 4 SCC cell lines by immunohistology and by PCR/SSCP. All lesions were classified histologically according to the dysplasia grade in benign lesions, respectively the loss of differentiation in the pre malignant and malignant lesions. The number of mutation detected by PCR/SSCP was much smaller in comparison with the immunohistology. Rb was detected in all carcinomas by immunohistology, indicating a normal protein. This result was confirmed by our PCR/ SCCP-analysis, where no mutations were detected. Mdm2 expression was detected in 35 % of all cases. The expression of mdm2 was highest in undifferentiated SCC, indicating a further inactivation of p53 in these tumors. Our investigation shows that genetic alternation of p53 and mdm2 expression play an important role in oral carcinogenesis. Rb function appears to be normal.

body_text.text: Leon Ardekian, Israel Kaffe, Michael Peleg, Shlomo Taicher Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Sheba Medical Center, Tel Hashomer and Department of Oral Pathology and Oral Medicine, School of Dental Medicine, Tel Aviv University, Israel Numerical data regarding the location of the mandibular foramen (MF) are essential for planning the site of surgical splitting of the ramus, especially in orthognathic surgery. In such cases determining the precise location of MF is important since failure to do so may lead to haemorrhage and permanent neurologic damage. Radiography is the only available non-invasive method for diagnosis and treatment planning of major surgical procedures of the mandible. Panoramic radiographs are commonly used for screening, diagnosis and selecting the best possible surgical approach. The reliability of two panoramic x-ray machines (Philips Orthoralix SD ceph and Gendex Panelipes II) for determination of the location of the MF was studied using 100 dry mandibles. A significant correlation was found between the location of the MF in radiographs and the narrowest anterior posterior dimension of the ramus. An equation was developed that could predict the actual location of the MF from the radiographs (using a linear logistic regression). This finding will improve treatment planning in cases requiring orthognathic surgery. The Philips Orthoralix SD was found to be more reliable for this purpose than the Panelipse II. (R2 = 0.94 or R2 = 0.87 respectively in the vertical dimension and R2 = 0.87 and R2 = 0.75 respectively in the horizontal dimension).

body_text.text: University" of Connecticut, USA Use of rigid internal fixation (RIF) has resulted in improved stability of the sagittal split mandibular ramus osteotomy (SSRO). body_text.text: Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, University Hospital, Groningen, The Netherlands This study was aimed to investigate whether cultured epithelial sheets can serve as a dressing for mucosal defects caused by vestibuloplasty. body_text.text: From eight patients (4 men, 4 woman; mean age of 43 years) a punch biopsy (o 3 mm) was taken from the palatal mucosa three weeks before vestibuloplasty. Epithelial cells were enzymatically dissociated from these tissue specimen. These cells were grown in vitro on a monolayer of lethally irradiated 3T3-mousefibroblasts in a humidified incubator at 37 °C and 5% CO2. The serum-containing culture medium was supplied with growth factors. Within three weeks, a 25 cm 2 multilayered epithelial sheet was cultured. The sheet was detached from the culture flask by enzyme treatment and layered out onto a carrier of sterile vaseline gauze (basal cells upwards). The sheet was placed on the mucosal defects (vestibuloplasty) and held in place by a relined denture fixed with perimandibular sutures. One week post surgery, the denture and vaseline gauzes were removed. Three months after vestibuloplasty, a punch biopsy (o 3 mm) was obtained. We did not register any postoperative abdominal complications in this study.In conclusion, there is after oncological surgery a nonpathological increase in serum amylase level. In case of postoperative abdominal pain it is necessary to evaluate the S and P isoamylase in order to exclude a postoperative pancreatitis.

Two series of experiments have been carried out on rats: the first on the OC of bone of different parts of the skeleton and the second on the correlation of OC with bulk and surface of the graft.These studies have shown that the BMP quantity increases in the following order: parietal bone, rib, iliac crest, femur, mandible. The quantity of IO decreases in the same sequence and the 'lability' of BMP increases in the very same sequence. Parietal bone possesses a low OC because it contains little BMP and a lot of IO. Iliac crest and rib have a medium quantity of BMP and IO, but the BMP is very labile. Mandible and femur have the best osteo-inductive capacity.

The aim of this study was to compare the microscopic differences between deep frozen and freeze dried allogeneic condyle grafts pretreated with DMSO and Glycerol, and to produce a satisfactory method of chondrocytes preservation for widespread application in Wonkwang University bone banking procedures. Comparison was made among four types: 1) Deep-frozen with DMSO, 2) Freeze-dried with DMSO, 3) Deep-frozen with Glycerol and 40 Freeze-dried with Glycerol. Inflammatory cell infiltration of articular surface was most severe in the Freeze-dried with Glycerol group and was least severe in the Deep-frozen with DMSO group. Viability of bone below the erosion zone showed few differences among four experimental groups. But the Glycerol groups were less viable than the DMSO groups. Degenerative change of condylar cartilage appeared after 1 week and disappeared after 6 weeks. The most intense change was in the Free-dried with Glycerol group. Maturing of condylar cartilage began at 2 weeks and there were no differences between Freeze-dried and Deep-frozen groups. There were no differences between the groups in the degree of endochondral ossification after 2 weeks. Our studies showed that Deep-frozen cryopreservation pretreated with DMSO offer an adequate preservation method of the osteochondral allografts.

Preoperative neoadjuvant chemotherapy is, apart from radiotherapy, a useful therapeutic agent in modern tumor therapy, especially in childhood rhabdomyosarcoma. Aside from tumor mass reduction, multiple morphological changes of blood vessels, even in normal tissue, can be found.Intravenous chemotherapy usually gives rise to general side effects. To explore these side effects, especially to the blood vessel system with regard to microsurgical flap transfer, TEM and REM studies were carried out on several tissue specimens of white laboratory rats after i.v. applications of several cytostatic drugs (Adriablastin, Bleomycin, Carboplatin, CDDP, D.T.I.C., Ifosfamide, MTX, Vincristine).Morphological changes were observed in venous and arterial bloodvessels and disturbance of the micro circulation could be found. Such effects lead to a high degree of vessel damage and capillary occlusion.These facts have to be kept in mind while planning and carrying out microsurgical flap transfer after chemotherapeutical treatment.

back_matter.text: One of the problems in the post-operative period after major maxillofacial surgery is nausea and vomiting which is particularly dangerous in patients who are brought to a ward instead of an intensive care unit.A study was carried out on 105 patients in order to compare the potency of anti-emetic drugs in the postoperative period. The purpose of this study was to verify the anti-emetic action of two drugs (ondansetron and metoclopramide).High doses of fentanyl (which emetic action is well known) were used for maintenance of the anesthesia and the use of droperidol, which is generally associated with fentanyl for its anti-emetic action was willingly avoided. A nasalgastric tube, which is normally used, was not brought in.The patients were divided in three groups: in the first group ondansetron, in the second group metoclopramide and in the last group a placebo was usedThe results of this study clearly demonstrate that ondansetron offers advantages over either metoclopramide or placebo and is capable of preventing post-operative nausea and vomiting in the majority of the patients.
